section-block.rac_essential-question: What foods do we like? Where do they come from?

section-block.rac_book_caption: Book: Before We Eat: From Farm to Table

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Pat Brisson, illustrated by Mary Azarian
section-block.rac_book_summary: All the food on the dinner table comes from somewhere. Many people work hard to bring others dinner—at the farm and the warehouse, in the grocery store and kitchen, and all the roads in between. So before we read, let’s take a minute to thank all the people who bring us food!

section-block.rac_body-text: Help children describe when they eat, using sentences that begin with when, before, and after, such as: “I eat breakfast after I get up.”
Invite children to sing to the tune of “Row, Row, Row Your Boat”: Fruits and veggies, eggs and bread, foods that keep us strong./ All the yummy foods we eat help us sing this song!

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Before We Eat: From Farm to Table by Pat Brisson, illustrated by Mary Azarian.
Scout loves informational books about food! Food is one of his favorite things to read about.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The family in the picture is ready to eat, but first they want to give thanks.
When the vegetables in the fields are ready to pick, it’s harvest time.
Harvest is an important part of getting food to the table.
What are the farmers on these pages doing?
The beekeeper is collecting honeybees. Listen to the words inside that word: honey, bees. Why do you think these insects have that name?
What different foods can you see in these pictures?
Let’s take turns naming all of the people who bring us the food we love to eat.
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment to Turn and Talk. Then, use Equity Sticks to pick 2 or 3 children to share:
As children watch and listen, write and read aloud short sentences about foods you enjoy. Invite children to expand your sentences with new words they have learned about how food gets to the table.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do vegetables and eggs come from farms?
Vegetables and eggs come from f___ (farms).
Vegetables and eggs come from farms.
What other foods come from farms?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children’s oral language, including sentence structure, will grow more sophisticated with opportunities for extended discussion. The weekly theme gives children just that—many occasions to talk about a high-interest topic. To encourage more complex sentences, ask children open-ended questions and expand on their answers.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Follow Rules and Routines
section-block.rac_body-text: Invite students to discuss classroom rules about food. Why do you have these rules? Share the routine Vocabulary Card. Discuss why we wash hands before eating. Talk about other food-related routines at school. Does the routine happen at the same time each day? What are the steps of the routine? (MB)

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to look for the follow rules and routines Mind Builder as we revisit the informational book Before We Eat by Pat Brisson.
This story shows different ways people help bring food to the table. Clifford loves learning about food and how it gets to us.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread and talk about some pages of the story to notice how people follow rules and routines.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Giving thanks for meals could be a rule as well as a routine. (MB)
Routines happen in a certain way, often in steps. What routine do we see here? As people get ready to grow food, what is the next step? (MB)
What would happen if the farmer didn’t collect the eggs or milk the cow?
Think about jobs you do in the classroom. What would happen if you didn’t do them? (MB)
What are the people in these pictures doing?
The mom is sharing an orange with the boy. What kind of fruit do you like to share with a friend?

section.rac_body-text: Before play, discuss classroom rules and routines, such as gathering for Circle Time and taking turns doing classroom jobs. Point out the importance of doing jobs that help the class.

Reinforce the importance of rules and routines by playing Guess the Game. Create a list of the rules or routines of a class activity. Say one rule or step at a time, without naming the activity. After each rule or step, use equity sticks to call on children to guess the classroom activity.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about classroom routines they enjoy.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Discussing the reasons for rules and routines is a great way to teach children important lessons about responsibility and community. Far from turning children into little robots, rules and routines, applied consistently and fairly, help children feel comfortable and gain confidence! (Vanderbilt, 2007)

section-block.rac_body-text: Review inferences: Say, Remember that sometimes the book gives us clues instead of telling us things.
Sing new words to “Wheels on the Bus”: The farmers in the field grow food for us... (Workers/warehouse/pack, People/kitchen/make). End verses with Let’s give thanks!

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the informational book Before We Eat by Pat Brisson.
Scout loves Before We Eat because he loves outdoor work.
This is the question I want you think about as we read:
How do farmers and workers get food to your dinner table?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and Day 3 prompts. During reading, use Equity Sticks to pick children to answer questions. Talk back and forth with children to help them explain their inferences about how tools and machines are used in food production.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Farmers plowed the ground so it can be ready for planting seeds.
These workers are taking care of the fields.
How are they taking care of the fields?
Who can describe what you see on these pages?
What jobs are these workers doing? Why do you think the open bins and the crates are different sizes?
Where do you think these truck drivers are going? What do you think is in their heavy loads?
section.rac_body-text: Point to the period after “chores.”
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What is this little dot at the end of this line in the book? What is it for?
Did you make inferences as we read the story today? Let’s see how much we figured out as we turn and talk about the guiding question:
How do farmers and workers get food to your dinner table?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, use Equity Sticks to choose 2 or 3 children to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Farmers plow the fields, then they plant.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to write about the farm-to-table trip. Invite children to add letters or end punctuation.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do farmers plow the fields to get ready to plant?
Farmers plow the f___(fields) to get ready to plant.
Farmers plow the fields to get ready to plant.
What else do farmers and workers do?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Consider using the pictures in Before We Eat to discuss technology in general. Point out the tractors, harvesters, and trucks. Point out that the checkout register, like tablets or phones children may have used, requires careful fingering and attention. Remind children that technology only works if the person uses it in the right way.

section-block.rac_body-text: Discuss with children all they have learned so far about their bodies and being healthy.
Have children take turns naming in English or their home language a kind of fruit they like and pretending to add it to an imaginary “fruit bowl” in the center of the circle.
Introduce new vocabulary from the Big Chart of Big Ideas.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Let’s Make Fruit Salad! It is an informational text in the form of a poster.
Scout loves informational posters, especially when the information is about food!
Before We Eat and Let’s Make Fruit Salad! focus on healthy foods. Let’s see if we find any other connections between the two!
As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question: What foods do we like? Where do they come from?
section.rac_body-text: Use these prompts to read and discuss the front of the poster.
Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to take turns responding.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to learn how to make fruit salad.
After I said, “Ingredients,” I read a list of things that go in fruit salad.
As I name each ingredient, help me find it in the picture. Let’s count how many. Can you say the numbers or fruit names in another language?
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show pages 8–9 of Before We Eat.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Could we make a salad from the foods we see here? What kind of salad would that be?
I’m going to read what we need to do in each step. After I read each step, you’ll take turns coming up and pointing to the picture that shows that step.

section.rac_body-text: Have students start making a fruit salad. Focus on washing and measuring the grapes and berries. Set up four tables for four groups. Place measuring cups and colanders (for rinsing grapes and berries) at each table, along with enough fruit for each group. When students have finished preparing the grapes and berries, have them mix them in a large bowl and set aside to enjoy later.
Provide a writing prompt about healthy foods we like, and give feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children learn by example. Model the process of learning a different language by learning a few words and phrases of your students’ first languages. Learn to say “hello” and “good job,” as well the names of foods. Post multilingual picture cards of various foods around the room. Little learners will be impressed by your efforts!

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to act out some of the food-related jobs they have read about this week. Encourage them to talk about the actions that they are dramatizing!
Sing about food-related jobs, to the tune of “Farmer in the Dell”: The farmer plows the fields....Hi-Ho the derry-o, the farmer plows the fields. Add other jobs named in the book.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book Before We Eat.
This informational book has words that have the same sound. These are called rhymes. Scout loves stories that rhyme.
This week we read all about people who work to bring food to our tables. As we read the book one more time, I want you to think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: If you could have any job in this book, which job would it be?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s pretend we each have a few seeds in our hands. Now show me how you plant the seeds.
These workers do many different tasks in the day. Show me how you would carry a basket full of vegetables.
Where is this man working? What is his job? How is this page different from the other pages?
Show me how you might sort good fruit from bad fruit.
What are the workers doing in these pictures?
When you are ready to pay for your food, the clerks are ready to help.
Show me what a clerk does when you go to pay for groceries.
I’ll point at each worker. Let’s name what job each one does.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: If you could have any job in this book, which job would it be?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Then, use Equity Sticks to pick 2 or 3 children to share. Possible responses:
Invite children to draw or talk about different food-related jobs. Then invite them to share their work with the class and celebrate their choices.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Would you like to deliver food in a truck?
I would like to deliver food in a tr________ (truck).
I would like to deliver food in a truck.
Would you want to be a farmer? Why or why not?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children in preschool absorb social studies concepts throughout the day as they learn and play together as a community. Before We Eat exposes children to important social studies concepts. Talking about the different food-related jobs provides a firm foundation for learning more about agriculture and division of labor in later years.
